channel.title: Bloomberg Economics

item.title: Australia Unexpectedly Holds Key Rate Steady, Currency Jumps
item.description: Australia’s central bank surprised investors and economists by keeping interest rates unchanged on Tuesday and signaled a wait-and-see approach on policy as US tariff plans stoke uncertainty across the world.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Thailand Confident of Lowering US Tariff With Trade Offers
item.description: Thailand remains optimistic about securing a lower tariff rate than the 36% levy announced by President Donald Trump, based on its offer to reduce import tax on most US goods to zero, Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira said.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana, Pathom Sangwongwanich

item.title: South Korea Vows to Fix Rules After Trump’s New Tariff Deadline
item.description: South Korea said it will look at regulations raised by the US and press ahead with trade negotiations after President Donald Trump sent a letter to the Asian ally with a new August deadline for imposing 25% across-the-board tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Heesu Lee

media:content.media:description: Container ships are docked as shipping containers sit in the Busan Port Terminal (BPT) in this aerial photograph taken in Busan, South Korea, on Tuesday, Oct. 13, 2020. South Korea’s central bank left its key interest rate unchanged on Wednesday amid signs that a resurgence of the coronavirus at home is waning and exports and inflation are picking up.

item.title: Will Trade War Make South India the Next Manufacturing Hub?
item.description: States like Tamil Nadu are dangling tax breaks and fast-tracking infrastructure, helping the country shake off its reputation as a difficult place to do business.
item.dc:creator: Dan Strumpf, Ruchi Bhatia

media:content.media:description: Putting the finishing touches on Ather scooters at the company’s factory in Hosur, Tamil Nadu.

item.title: Romania to Hold Rates as Tax Changes Hit Prices: Decision Guide
item.description: Romania’s central bank is likely to leave borrowing costs unchanged as the government’s recently announced tax hikes are expected to trigger a new spike in inflation over the coming months.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: The Romanian central bank in Bucharest, Romania.

item.title: US Clouds Malaysia Rate Path With Surprise Threat of 25% Tariff
item.description: The surprise US decision to raise its threatened tariff on Malaysia to 25% means trade will almost certainly dominate the Southeast Asian nation’s interest rate decision on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Anisah Shukry

item.title: Malaysia Commits to Trade Talks After Higher US Tariff Threat
item.description: Malaysia said it will continue to engage with the US after President Donald Trump threatened to impose a steeper tariff rate unless the Southeast Asian nation reaches an agreement with his administration.
item.dc:creator: Anisah Shukry

item.title: Japan, Korea Keep Pushing for Lower US Tariffs as Deadline Moves
item.description: Japan and South Korea said they’ll keep pushing for a better deal for their exports to the US after President Donald Trump shifted his tariff deadline to Aug. 1 and tweaked the rates he’s set for many economies.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara, Soo-Hyang Choi

item.title: China Shuns Costly LNG Imports Even as Summer Power Demand Rises
item.description: Sweltering temperatures are pushing up appetite for electricity in China — just not yet enough to revive the country’s spot purchases of costly liquefied natural gas.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Stapczynski, Kathy Chen

item.title: Japan Gets 25% Tariffs With Room to Seek Deal Past Election
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba called the announcement of slightly higher US tariffs “truly regrettable” while he vowed to continue to protect his nation’s interests in the extended trade negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

item.title: Affordable Homes in India Dwindle to 7-Year Low, Report Shows
item.description: India’s supply of houses costing less than 5 million rupees ($58,553) fell to their lowest since 2018, a Knight Frank report found, signaling that the trend of developers pivoting away from this segment continues.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Ajith

item.title: Australia Business Conditions and Confidence Jump Ahead of RBA Decision
item.description: Australian business conditions jumped as sales, profitability and employment surged while confidence also climbed, suggesting a recovery in the corporate sector may be unfolding in line with the Reserve Bank’s easing cycle.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Japan’s Early June Exports Rise Slightly Ahead of Higher Tariffs
item.description: Japan’s exports edged up in the first 20 days of June ahead of the Trump administration’s scheduled imposition of higher tariffs as US policy continues to impact trade flows.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

item.title: Colombian Inflation Slows More Than Forecast to 4.82%
item.description: Colombia’s inflation rate dropped to its lowest level in nearly four years, potentially bolstering the case of the central bank minority who voted for an interest rate cut last month.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Medina

item.title: Fund Managers Bet on Bank, Consumer Stocks After India Rate Cuts
item.description: Money managers are betting Indian banking and consumption stocks have further to run this year, benefiting from the central bank’s aggressive policy rate cuts to lift economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Abhishek Vishnoi

item.title: Ghana Unlocks $367 Million Disbursement From IMF After Review
item.description: Ghana will receive another $367 million disbursement from the International Monetary Fund after passing the fourth review of its $3 billion program with the Washington-based lender.
item.dc:creator: Ekow Dontoh

item.title: トランプ大統領による日本への25％関税通告と金融市場の動向

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump speaks to members of the media on the South Lawn of the White House before boarding Marine One in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, July 1, 2025. Trump threatened to withdraw government subsidies from Elon Musk’s companies and examine the billionaire’s immigration status after the Tesla Inc. chief executive officer ratcheted up his criticism of the president’s tax and spending bill.

item.title: Carney’s Cabinet Searches for Spending Cuts as Defense Bill Grows
item.description: Canada’s finance minister has asked members of cabinet to find billions of dollars in spending cuts as the government looks for ways to pay for a larger defense budget and capital projects.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt

media:content.media:description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney, right, and Minister of National Defence David McGuinty meet with Canadian troops at the Fort York Armoury in Toronto, on June 9.

item.title: Tracking Every Trump Tariff and Its Economic Effect
item.description: For the full experience visit: Tracking Every Trump Tariff and Its Economic Effect
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Diamond, Adrian Leung, Jane Pong, Christopher Udemans, Jason Kao

item.title: ECB’s Villeroy Sees Quantitative Easing as Best Unconventional Policy Tool
item.description: The European Central Bank’s best unconventional instrument for steering monetary policy is large-scale asset purchases, according to Governing Council member Francois Villeroy de Galhau.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Langley, Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Governor of France's central bank Francois Villeroy De Galhau.

item.title: Fed Study Finds 9% Chance of Rates Hitting Zero in Medium Term
item.description: The Federal Reserve can’t assume its benchmark lending rate won’t return to zero at some point in the future, according to researchers from the Federal Reserve Banks of New York and San Francisco, who included New York Fed President John Williams.
item.dc:creator: Maria Eloisa Capurro

item.title: S&P Sees Trump Tax Law Hurting State and Hospital Balance Sheets
item.description: President Donald Trump’s new budget bill is expected to push almost 12 million Americans off their health insurance, creating long-term financial issues for states and health-care providers, according to a S&P Global report.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Kaske

media:content.media:description: An examination room is seen at the Oscar Center in the Brooklyn borough of New York, U.S., on Wednesday, Dec. 7, 2016. The Oscar Center runs in partnership with Mount Sinai Health Systems providing primary care services and health and wellness programs. Photographer: Kholood Eid/Bloomberg

item.title: RBNZ Seen Holding Rates While Leaving Door Open to Further Cuts
item.description: New Zealand’s central bank is expected to keep interest rates on hold this week amid uncertainty over the inflation outlook while leaving the door open to further easing if needed to bolster the weak economy.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Brockett

media:content.media:description: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) building in Wellington, New Zealand, on Wednesday, Feb. 19, 2025. New Zealand’s central bank cut interest rates by 50 basis points for the third straight meeting to help revive the ailing economy and signaled more easing in coming quarters.

item.title: Trump Leaves Room for Negotiations After Tariff Letters

media:content.media:description: A container ship docked at the Port of Cape Town in South Africa. Photographer: Dwayne Senior/Bloomberg

item.title: Donohoe Retains Eurogroup Role to Push Currency’s Ascendancy
item.description: Paschal Donohoe won reelection as president of the euro area’s group of finance ministers, retaining a leading role in the region’s efforts to enhance the profile of its common currency.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Michal Kubala, Daniel Basteiro, Milda Seputyte

media:content.media:description: Paschal Donohoe, president of Eurogroup, during a news conference following a Eurogroup meeting in Brussels, Belgium, on Monday, Jan. 20, 2025. As Donald Trump prepares to be sworn in as president today, Europe's leaders are bracing for the first batch of executive orders and their potential impact on the region. Photographer: Simon Wohlfahrt/Bloomberg

item.title: Chile’s Biggest Copper Windfall in Years Signals Higher Output
item.description: Chilean copper mines had their best month of export revenue in more than three years in June, with the increase in value outstripping price gains in a sign of rising production.
item.dc:creator: James Attwood

item.title: Israel Holds Rates and Cuts Growth Forecast for This Year
item.description: Israel’s central bank kept interest rates unchanged for the 12th consecutive time, giving a recent rally in the shekel more time to slow inflation and pave the way for lower borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Galit Altstein

media:content.media:description: Shoppers at Carmel market in Tel Aviv, Israel, on Friday, June 13, 2025. Israel launched airstrikes across Iran on Friday morning, targeting nuclear facilities and killing senior military commanders in a major escalation that could spark a broad war in the Middle East.

item.title: BRICS Tread With Caution After Trump Threatens New Tariffs
item.description: BRICS officials kept their collective heads down on Monday morning as they awoke to an overnight threat by US President Donald Trump to penalize them for adopting policies he said were “anti-American.”
item.dc:creator: Simone Iglesias, Mirette Magdy

media:content.media:description: Brazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva during a BRICS summit plenary session on July 6.

item.title: UK Races to Get US to Cut Steel Tariffs Ahead of Key Deadline
item.description: The UK is racing to secure US agreement to make operational a deal to eliminate tariffs on British steel ahead of a Wednesday deadline when American officials could choose instead to raise the levy to 50%.
item.dc:creator: Alex Morales, Joe Mayes

media:content.media:description: A steel finishing plant in Sheffield, UK.

item.title: Canadians’ Job Security Gets Shakier as Trade War Harms Growth
item.description: Canadians are becoming less optimistic about their job prospects as the economy struggles to find momentum.
item.dc:creator: Paula Sambo

media:content.media:description: Commuters exit a subway station in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, on Friday, June 7, 2024. Amalgamated Transit Union has reached a framework settlement with the Toronto Transit Commission, the union said in a statement, avoiding a strike that threatened to disrupt more than 1.5 million commuters.
